sentences.sentence: A few days later, Mr. Darcy and Mr. Bingley came to Longbourn.
The gentlemen arrived early.
Bingley, who wanted to be alone with Jane, suggested they all take a walk together, and this was agreed to.
Mrs. Bennet was not in the habit of walking, and Mary said she was too busy, but the other five set off together.
Bingley and Jane, however, soon fell behind the others, and Elizabeth, Kitty, and Darcy walked on together.
There was very little conversation.
Kitty was too much afraid of Darcy to talk, and Elizabeth was secretly forming a desperate( 孤注一掷的 ) plan, and wondering if Darcy perhaps might be doing the same.
They walked toward the Lucases, because Kitty wanted to see Maria.
When Kitty left them, Elizabeth continued boldly( 大胆地 ) on alone with Darcy.
Now was the moment to act out her plan, and, while she was still feeling brave, she immediately said:
“Mr. Darcy, I am a very selfish woman, and I must tell you my feelings( 感受 ), even at the risk of wounding yours.
I can no longer keep from thanking you for your exceptional kindness to my poor sister.
Ever since I have known about it, I have been very eager to tell you how grateful I am to you.
If the rest of my family also knew what you had done for them, I would not be the only one with gratitude( 感激之情 ) to express.”
“I am sorry, extremely sorry,” replied Darcy, in a tone( 语气 ) of surprise and emotion( 激动 ),
“that you were ever told about something which may, if misunderstood, have made you feel uneasy.
I thought that Mrs. Gardiner would have been more trustworthy( 值得信赖的 ) in keeping a secret.”
“You must not blame my aunt.
It was Lydia’s thoughtlessness that first revealed( 透露 ) to me that you had been involved in the matter.
I, of course, could not stop until I knew the details( 细节 ).
Let me thank you again and again, in the name of all my family, for your generous compassion( 同情心 ).”
“If you will thank me,” he replied, “thank me for yourself alone.
I did what I did only because I wanted to make you happy.
I will not try to deny( 否认 ) that.
But your family owes( 欠 ) me nothing.
As much as I respect them, I admit that I only thought about you.”
Elizabeth was much too embarrassed( 尴尬的 ) to say anything.
After a short pause, Darcy added, “I know that you are too kindhearted( 好心的 ) to play games with me.
If you still feel as you did last April, tell me so right now.
My feelings( 感受 ) and desires have not changed, but if you still think of me as you did before, I will never mention a single word on this subject again.”
Elizabeth felt extremely awkward( 尴尬的 ) and nervous in such an extraordinary situation, but she now forced herself to speak.
She immediately, though not very fluently( 顺畅地 ), explained to him that her feelings( 感受 ) were greatly changed, and that she now happily received and returned his affection( 喜爱 ).
When Darcy heard these words, he felt more happiness than he had perhaps ever felt before.
He expressed his feelings( 感受 ) to her as emotionally( 激动地 ) and as warmly as a man passionately( 热情地 ) in love can possibly do.
If Elizabeth had been able to look at his face, she might have seen how handsome he looked while wearing an expression of heartfelt( 衷心的 ) delight.
Though she could not look, she could listen.
He told her his feelings( 感受 ), and how important she was to him, and so his affection( 喜爱 ) became every moment more precious( 宝贵的 ) to her.
They walked on, without knowing in what direction—there was so much to be thought, and felt, and said.
She soon learnt that they owed( 欠 ) their present good understanding to the efforts of his aunt,
who called on him on her return from Longbourn and told him in great detail( 细节 ) about her conversation with Elizabeth,
emphasizing( 强调 ) everything Elizabeth had said which, in her ladyship’s opinion, demonstrated( 详述 ) Elizabeth’s perverseness( 倔强 ) and obstinacy( 顽固 ).
She believed that this would help her obtain( 获得 ) that promise from her nephew which Elizabeth had refused to give,
but unluckily for her ladyship( 夫人 ), it had had the exactly opposite( 相反的 ) effect.
“It taught me to hope,” said he, “as I had scarcely( 几乎没有 ) ever allowed myself to hope before.
I knew enough of your disposition( 性情 ) to be certain that, had you been absolutely( 完全地 ), irrevocably( 不可撤回地 ) decided against me,
you would have acknowledged( 承认 ) it to Lady Catherine, frankly( 坦白地 ) and openly.”
Elizabeth blushed( 脸红 ) and laughed as she replied, “Yes, you know enough of my frankness( 率直 ) to believe me capable( 能胜任的 ) of that.
After abusing( 辱骂 ) you so horribly( 糟糕地 ) to your face, why would I not abuse( 辱骂 ) you to all your relations?”
“What did you say of me, that I did not deserve? For, though your accusations( 指责 ) were not completely accurate( 准确的 ), my behavior to you at the time was unpardonable.
I cannot think of it without shame.”
“We will not quarrel about who was most to blame that evening,” said Elizabeth.
“The conduct of neither of us, if strictly examined, would escape some blame.
But since then we have both, I hope, improved in civility.”
“I cannot so easily make peace with myself.
The memory( 记忆 ) of what I said, of my conduct, my manners, my expressions during the whole of it, is now, and has been many months, inexpressibly( 难以言状地 ) painful to me.
Your rebuke( 斥责 ), so well applied, I shall never forget: ‘had you behaved in a more gentlemanlike( 有礼貌的 ) manner.’
You cannot imagine how those words have tortured( 使痛苦 ) me—though it was some time, I confess( 承认 ), before I was able to see their truth.”
“I was certainly very far from expecting them to make so strong an impression. ”
“I can easily believe it.
I shall never forget the look on your face as you said that I could not have asked you in any possible way that would cause you to accept me.”
“Oh! Do not repeat what I then said—I do not want to remember it, and I assure( 保证 ) you that I have long been most heartily( 由衷地 ) ashamed of it.
You must learn some of my philosophy( 人生观 ): think of the past only when the memory( 记忆 ) gives you pleasure.”
“I cannot give you credit for any philosophy( 人生观 ) of the kind.
The contentment arising from your memories( 记忆 ) is not of philosophy( 人生观 ), but, what is much better, of innocence.
But with me, it is not so. I have been a selfish being all my life, in practice, though not in principle.
I was taught when young to care for none beyond my own family circle, and to think meanly of all the rest of the world.
Such I was from eight to twenty-eight, and such I might still have been but for you, dearest, loveliest Elizabeth!
You taught me a lesson, hard indeed at first, but most advantageous.
By you, I was properly humbled( 被打败 ).
I came to you without a doubt of my reception.
You showed me how insufficient( 不足的 ) were all my efforts to please a woman worthy of being pleased.”
“How you must have hated me after that evening!”
“I was angry perhaps at first, but my anger soon began to take a proper direction.”
“I am almost afraid to ask what you thought of me when we met at Pemberley.
Did you blame me for coming?”
“No indeed; I felt nothing but surprise.”
“Your surprise could not be greater than mine.
My conscience( 良心 ) told me that I did not deserve the extraordinary politeness you showed to me.”
“My object then,” replied Darcy, “was to show you, by every civility in my power, that I was not so mean as to resent( 怨恨 ) the past.
I also hoped to obtain( 获得 ) your forgiveness by showing you that your criticisms( 批评 ) of my behavior had been heard and attended( 注意 ) to.
How soon any other wishes introduced themselves I can hardly tell, but I believe in about half an hour after I had seen you.”

question.cn: 谁第一个向Elizabeth透露Mr. Darcy介入了Lydia和Wickham的婚礼？
question.en: According to Elizabeth, who was the first one to reveal Mr. Darcy's involvement in the matter to her?

analysis: 文中Elizabeth说到：“You must not blame my aunt. It was Lydia's thoughtlessness that first revealed to me that you had been involved in the matter.” 所以选A。

question.cn: Mr. Darcy为什么要为Elizabeth和她的家人做这么多？
question.en: Why did Mr. Darcy do so much to help Elizabeth and her family?

options.cn: 因为他想让大家知道他是一个多好的人。
options.en: He did it because he wanted everyone to know what a nice man he was.
He did it because he cared about everyone equally.
He did it all with Elizabeth in mind and wanted her to be happy.

analysis: 文中对话中提到：“But your family owes me nothing. As much as I respect them, I admit that I only thought about you.” 所以选C。

question.cn: 在Mr. Darcy披露一切后，Elizabeth觉得Mr. Darcy怎么样？
question.en: How did Elizabeth feel about Mr. Darcy after his revelation?

options.en: She still thought he was disagreeable.

options.cn: 她高兴地接受了他的喜欢并且也表达了自己的感情。
options.en: She happily received his affection and returned hers.

options.cn: 她的感情还是没有改变。
options.en: Her feelings were not changed at all.

analysis: 文中提到：“She immediately, though not very fluently, explained to him that her feelings were greatly changed, and that she now happily received and returned his affection.” 所以选B。
